utterances: No correction, all right.
Excuse me?
Well, it was rejected by...
All right.
Anyway, so I was wrong.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Ken Rudin is with us, as you just heard.
And those voices chiming in are those of Vin Weber, the former Republican member of the House of Representatives in Minnesota, now a Republican strategist and a lobbyist here in Washington, D.C.
Anna Greenberg also with us, senior vice president and principal of Greenberg Quinlan and Rosner, a Democratic pollster, worked on the campaigns of Bill Clinton and Al Gore.
And thank you both for joining us again.
They've been kind enough to be with us several times through the campaign.
And let me ask both of you, these Quinnipiac polls are maybe outliers but they're interesting in that they show Obama with significant leads in these three key swing states.
And you'd have to think, Vin, that John McCain would have to win all three of those.
I think you're right.
There's no question that the last two weeks, just to pick a timeframe, have shown a trend toward the Democrats across the board.
John McCain has lost ground to Obama.
Nationally, he's lost ground in just about every swing state, maybe except in New Hampshire, although maybe you know something I don't.
But it's across the board.
It's related directly to the economic problem.

The only thing I would say as a Republican is at any time on this race since at least the beginning of summer, if we had looked at a two-week or three-week period of time and said, if present trends continue...
Continue.
This is what's going to happen, we would have been wrong.
I mean, you know, Obama had a couple of weeks after he locked up the nomination in June.
Then in July, McCain had a surge and he almost got it even at the time of the Democratic Convention.
And then Obama surged ahead a little bit.
And then McCain surged ahead a little bit.
This is certainly a surge for the Democrats, but I think that to project this out for 30 days is a mistake.

It depends on what's going to happen with the bailout on Capitol Hill, it's going to depend on what happens in the real economy, and it's going to depend on what other issues come up in the course of the next 30 days.
And of course, it depends on the debates.
And it's been a volatile time.

But Anna Greenberg, as you look at it - as you look at the blue states and red states, the 51 battlegrounds that we've got, you can't see - I don't see looking at that that there are any blue states, states than John Kerry won where Barack Obama is not in the lead.
Some are narrow, but he seems to be in the lead in all of them.
That's right.
The only blue states that are close are New Hampshire, Wisconsin.
I think that Michigan looks now pretty solidly, you know, going to vote for Obama, and actually, Pennsylvania's looking pretty solid.
But I want just to pick up on one thing that Vin talked about.
It is true that part of what's happened over the last - I would say, three weeks - is the - to survive economic crisis.
And in general, economic issues tend to favor Democrats when those are the most important issues.
But there's been other things that have been happening.
I think that Sarah Palin has become a significant drag on the McCain-Palin ticket.
You've seen her favorability drop considerably in response to a lot of different things.
And also, I think McCain...
Which she could reverse very quickly tomorrow night.
Sure.
Maybe.
I mean, it's going to be hard.

And then you've got McCain, I think, sort of losing his footing a bit, starting with the fundamentals of the economy are sound and then, you know, the alleged suspension, and then uncertainty about the debate.

And then we've seen some real movement for Obama on underlying measures that are really important around leadership and being up to the job, especially after this debate on national security, war on terrors and foreign policy.
Reputation.
Is he seen as a standard Republican?
(Soundbite of TV series, ""House"")

So it is true that this has been a very unpredictable presidential race but I think that there are some things happening below the surface that make it that much harder for McCain and Palin to come back.
And is this...
So Anna is saying present trends are going to continue.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yes.
They favor her side.
But as you look ahead to this, is this coincidental with the debate?
Did the debate - Vin, do you think, change minds?
I think the debate did change minds.
I don't think it turned anyone against John McCain but I think that Barack Obama did well.
And he needed to establish, sort of, a threshold level of credibility, particularly on foreign policy issues, and he performed well enough to do that.
That's going into the debate, that's what everybody said that he had to do, and I think he did.
Absolutely.

I mean, the dial groups that we did that night and looking pre-post to the debate, we saw less movement on economic issues - where I think, actually, it was sort of a draw, the first 40 minutes - and big movement on all these issues of foreign policy.
And I think there's an assumption that McCain should be better on these issues.
But I think that's been an assumption.
I actually think that, you know, Obama's always been pretty strong and conversant and people just need to see it on the national stage.
Let's see if we can get some listeners in on the conversation.
And let's go with Jennifer.
Jennifer with us from Tallahassee in Florida, very much a swing state, as comes as a surprise to nobody.
Hi.
Hi, Jennifer.
We haven't seen a lot here.
We're kind of the different country from Florida because we're North Florida and not South Florida.
The wives have been here a couple of times doing voter registration drive, being Michelle Obama and Joe Biden.
But there hasn't been a ton of commercials, and there hasn't been a ton of press.
Tallahassee up in the northern part of Florida, as she was saying.
And you would think that that's pretty much the Republican parts of the state of Florida, should be - and of course, Pensacola...
And only Obama has been on the air in Florida.
Now I think that McCain's going to have to go up on the air because it's becoming so competitive.
So it's moving into a different column from McCain.
I think that's potentially problematic given that he's got some sniffing-at-resource constrains that Obama doesn't have.
McCain is not airing advertising in Florida?
He has not been, no. Just Obama.
He's had, actually, a more solid lead than we thought he might have had in Florida, given that swing state status up until now.
So he hasn't felt the need of advertising.
The swing vote in - or the big question mark over Florida, I think, and you'll probably agree with me, is what's happening with the Hispanic vote this time around?
Republicans have usually been able to dominate the Hispanic vote, which is predominantly - not entirely, but predominantly - Cuban-American in South Florida.
There's some indication that that might be changing, particularly among younger Cubans this time, Cuban-Americans.
And we'll just have to see.
If that happens, that could mark or make a significant change in Florida.
But I want to point out, until this economic downturn - political downturn...
Right.
McCain was actually holding a larger lead in Florida than we might have anticipated.
But then just to follow up - and Jennifer, thanks very much for the phone call.
Thank you.

But just to follow up, one of the things that Barack Obama, the Democrats wanted to do this year was to say we can force the Republicans to spend time and money in a lot of places where they haven't had to spend time and money before.
We may not win in Virginia and North Carolina, Georgia but we will force them to spend time and effort there.
Yes.
And I think that they've largely succeeded in that.

The Republicans are still trying to put them on the defensive in a few places, in Pennsylvania and Michigan, although I agree with Anna, it looks like Michigan is firm for the other side, maybe Wisconsin.
But by and large, the battleground states right now, the states that are genuinely competitive right now, are states that were all red last time around.
And I would just add that now McCain is spending Indiana, which is little bit astonishing.
Obama's been up there for a long time but they're spending in Virginia, which they came too late and they, I believe, if they're not already, they're going to be spending in North Carolina.
Let's get another caller on the line.
This is Kitty, Kitty with us from Reno in Nevada.
Hi there.
Hi, Kitty.
Hi, I'm actually a county commissioner here in Reno Washoe County.
And I have been canvassing for myself going door to door.
And I'll tell you - and I don't go to just Democrats, I go to everyone.
And it's interesting, everybody wants to talk about the campaign but there is no true line when it comes to the independents, bipartisans and Republicans.
I mean, many of them are very unpredictable of whom they will support, and startlingly unpredictable that they don't want anybody who's a Republican from their point of view.
And as you probably know, Washoe County is a huge battleground county.
And the other issue is McCain hasn't had much of a presence at all yet.
I guess they said, in the next couple of weeks we'll see a lot of paid staffers canvassing the area.
But the Obama campaign brings in about 400 people every weekend, young people from California, to help canvas.
Well, I mean, the - we had a huge Ron Paul contingency here.
Nevada tends to swing quite libertarian, at least in the past.
So he can't win for losing on either one of those sides.
OK.
And is Barack Obama seen as a standard Democrat?
You know, I think he's as standard as a Democrat is that is palatable for this state and definitely northern Nevada.
Nevada, one of the swing states where John McCain's doing a little bit better.
